question: Why should I be a doctor just because I'm good at Biology? I mean, I like music more.
I enjoy playing video games, does that mean I should become a professional gamer?
I'm really organized and I love planning events for my friends. What kind of job could that lead to?
I love watching courtroom dramas on TV. Should I become a lawyer?
My parents say I argue a lot. Maybe I should be a politician?
Haha, well, debating is indeed a part of politics! But remember, there's much more to it. Let's explore what a career in politics really involves.
I love making my friends laugh. Should I just run off and join the circus?
Well, unless you also have a passion for tightrope walking, let's explore careers in comedy or entertainment first!
So, for my resume, should I list all the games I've won in Fortnite?
Can I just write, "I'm awesome, hire me" on my resume?
So, should I include that I was voted "Class Clown" for my senior year?
Can I start my cover letter with "Hey there, future boss!"?
While it's important to show your personality, it's also crucial to maintain professionalism. Let's find a balance between the two!
So, in my cover letter, should I just tell them I'm the best person for the job?
Should I tell them that my mom thinks I'm a hard worker in my cover letter?
Can I just tell them I need the job to fund my comic book collection?
Well, honesty is appreciated but let's focus on how the job aligns with your career goals and how you can contribute to the company.
So, for the "Tell me about yourself" question, should I start with my kindergarten years?
If they ask about my weaknesses, should I say I care too much?
So, for networking, should I just start emailing random people asking for a job?
While initiative is good, let's start with building relationships first. You know, like making friends, but with a professional twist!
If I want to network, should I just start adding everyone on LinkedIn?
So, if networking is about building relationships, can I invite potential connections to play video games with me?
That's one way to bond, but remember, professional boundaries are important. Let's think of more professional settings or activities to connect over.
For job shadowing, can I just follow around my favorite teacher all day?
If I job shadow a chef, do I get to eat all the food?
So, for job shadowing, should I dress like a secret agent and bring binoculars?
It's not quite that clandestine! You'll want to dress professionally and remember, your "mission" is to learn as much as you can about the job.
So, if I get an internship at a tech company, do I get to boss around the robots?
Not quite, but you'll certainly get hands-on experience with real projects. And who knows, maybe you'll get to program a robot or two!
Can I do an internship as a superhero sidekick?
If I intern at a bakery, can I eat all the pastries?
While that sounds like a delicious plan, it's more about learning the craft and business of baking. But, sure, a pastry or two might come your way!
If I volunteer at a zoo, will I get to ride the elephants?
Well, that's probably unlikely (and unsafe). But you'll certainly learn a lot about animal care and conservation, which can be very rewarding!
So, if I volunteer at the library, can I just read all day?
If I volunteer to clean up the park, do I get to keep anything cool I find?
While you might find something interesting, the real treasure is the experience and the satisfaction of making a positive impact on your community.
If I want to be an astronaut, do I have to start by being an alien first?
Haha, no, not quite! But studying science, particularly physics and engineering, and gaining experience in related fields would be a great start.
So, to be a chef, do I have to start as a dishwasher?
If I want to be a CEO, can I just start my own company now?
So, if I can catch a marshmallow in my mouth from across the room, is that a soft skill?
My friends always come to me with their problems. Does that mean I'm good at troubleshooting?
I'm great at persuading my little brother to do my chores. Is that a soft skill?
I'm great at building pillow forts. Is that a technical skill?
I've mastered all the levels on my favorite video game. Is that a technical skill?
I can make a mean grilled cheese sandwich. Is that a technical skill?
For career planning, can I just spin a globe and pick a random country to work in?
So, for career planning, should I just follow in my dad's footsteps and become a clown?
Can I just flip a coin to decide my career path?
So, if I play video games for eight hours a day, that's work-life balance, right?
Can I achieve work-life balance by doing my homework while watching TV?
If I sleep in class, does that count as work-life balance?
So, if I sell my old comic books, does that make me an entrepreneur?
Can I become an entrepreneur by starting a pet sitting business for the neighborhood squirrels?
If I charge my brother for doing his chores, is that entrepreneurship?
